t: Job 18
Bildad Speaks: God Punishes the Wicked
Then*p Bildad the Shuhite answered and said:
“How*pn long will you hunt for words? Consider,*ld and then we will speak.
Why*ln are we counted as cattle? Why*ld are we stupid in your sight?
You*ln who tear yourself in your anger, shall*ld the earth be forsaken for you, or*ld the rock be removed out of its place?
“Indeed,*pn the light of the wicked is put out, and*ld the flame of his fire does not shine.
The*ln light is dark in his tent, and*ld his lamp above him is put out.
His*ln strong steps are shortened, and*ld his own schemes throw him down.
For*ln he is cast into a net by his own feet, and*ld he walks on its mesh.
A*ln trap seizes him by the heel; a*ld snare lays hold of him.
A*ln rope is hidden for him in the ground, a*ld trap for him in the path.
Terrors*ln frighten him on every side, and*ld chase him at his heels.
His*ln strength is famished, and*ld calamity is ready for his stumbling.
It*ln consumes the parts of his skin; the*ld firstborn of death consumes his limbs.
He*ln is torn from the tent in which he trusted and*ld is brought to the king of terrors.
In*ln his tent dwells that which is none of his; sulfur*ld is scattered over his habitation.
His*ln roots dry up beneath, and*ld his branches wither above.
His*ln memory perishes from the earth, and*ld he has no name in the street.
He*ln is thrust from light into darkness, and*ld driven out of the world.
He*ln has no posterity or progeny among his people, and*ld no survivor where he used to live.
They*ln of the west are appalled at his day, and*ld horror seizes them of the east.
Surely*ln such are the dwellings of the unrighteous, such*ld is the place of him who knows not God.”
